questions.question: What are the three distinct components that make up a single nucleotide?
options: A pentose sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base
A glucose molecule, an amino group, and a non-polar lipid tail
A glycerol backbone, three fatty acids, and a phosphate molecule
An amino acid monomer, a carboxyl group, and a variable R-group
questions.explanation: Every nucleotide is composed of a five-carbon (pentose) sugar, at least one phosphate group, and one of five nitrogenous bases.

questions.question: Which pentose sugar is found specifically in the nucleotides that form DNA?
questions.explanation: DNA contains deoxyribose, which lacks an oxygen atom on the $$2'$$ carbon compared to the ribose sugar found in RNA.

questions.question: To which carbon atom of the pentose sugar is the nitrogenous base always attached?
questions.explanation: The nitrogenous base is linked to the $$1'$$ (one-prime) carbon of the sugar via a glycosidic bond.

questions.question: Which carbon atom of the pentose sugar is bonded to the phosphate group?
questions.explanation: The phosphate group is attached to the $$5'$$ (five-prime) carbon of the pentose sugar.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between a purine and a pyrimidine base?
options: Purines have a double-ring structure, while pyrimidines have a single-ring structure
Purines are found only in RNA strands, while pyrimidines are found only in DNA
Purines contain organic phosphorus, while pyrimidines contain organic sulfur
Purines are highly hydrophilic, while pyrimidines are entirely hydrophobic
questions.explanation: Purines (Adenine and Guanine) consist of a six-membered ring fused to a five-membered ring. Pyrimidines (Cytosine, Thymine, and Uracil) consist of a single six-membered ring.

questions.question: Which of the following nitrogenous bases is classified as a purine?
questions.explanation: Adenine (A) and Guanine (G) are the two purine bases found in both DNA and RNA.

questions.question: Which nitrogenous base is found exclusively in RNA and replaces thymine?
questions.explanation: Uracil is the pyrimidine base unique to RNA; it pairs with adenine, similar to how thymine pairs with adenine in DNA.

questions.question: What is the name of a molecule that consists of only a pentose sugar and a nitrogenous base, without a phosphate group?
questions.explanation: A nucleoside is the sugar-base combination. Once a phosphate group is added, it becomes a nucleotide (specifically a nucleoside monophosphate).

questions.question: Which nucleotide is known as the 'universal energy currency' of the cell?
questions.explanation: ATP is an RNA nucleotide with two extra phosphate groups; the energy stored in the bonds between these phosphates powers cellular work.

questions.question: In a polynucleotide chain, the $$3'$$ carbon of one sugar is linked to the $$5'$$ phosphate of the next. What is this bond called?
questions.explanation: Phosphodiester bonds form the strong covalent 'backbone' of nucleic acid strands.
